original_title: Sri Lanka chicken demand falls after currency collapse, inflation: poultry group
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Demand for chicken in Sri Lanka fell in the fourth quarter of 2022 as high inflation in the wake of a currency collapse reduced disposable incomes, Ceylon Grain Elevators, a top poultry group said.
Group revenue which includes feed milling, hatchery and chicken sales fell 36 percent to 3.1 billion rupees in the December quarter from a year ago.
In the first nine months revenue from chicken had risen as prices and demand rose. Sri Lanka’s fish prices also soared in 2022 as diesel shortages hit fishermen.

“However, the demand for chicken declined in the final quarter due to the inclement weather and the effect of increased inflation levels that created pressure on the disposable income of the consumers,” Chief Executive, Cheng Chih Kwong, Primus, told shareholders.
“This was further exacerbated by the increase in the VAT which affected the affordability of products creating a decline in demand
Amid higher taxes profits fell 9 percent to 971 million rupees.
The firm said a cascading social security contribution levy had also hit the firm.
In the first half feed production had been hit by shortages in imported feed amid forex shortages and higher prices.

Sri Lanka’s rupee fell from 200 to 360 to the US dollar in 2022 after the central bank printed money to mis-target interest rates and botched a float with a surrender rule pushing the currency down steeply.
The currency fall was arrested by newly appointed Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe who hiked rates and re-pegged the curcency at 360/370 to the US dollar, analysts say.

Since its creation the central bank had depreciated the currency from 4.70 to the US dollar by mis-targeting rates for various reasons, including re-financed credit, yield curve targeting, sterilized interventions and deliberately targeting levels of inflation as high as 5 percent.
Ceylon Grain Elevators said it made a 5.1 billion rupee forex loss, in 2022. The firm had run suppliers’ credit during forex shortages to keep the country supplied with food. (Colombo/Feb23/2023)
